TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He was represented before the ORG by Mr A. Hajdari , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their then Agents , PERSON and PERSON .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant entered into a loan contract with a private company , ORG , through CARDINAL of its shareholders , ORG He agreed to lend the amount of MONEY from DATE to CARDINAL DATE , with an interest rate of MONEY per month . When the company defaulted , the applicant lodged an action with GPE to recover the debt under the loan contract .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Vlora ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) ordered ORG , which was represented by PERSON to pay back the principal amount , including the interest accrued . In the absence of an appeal , ORG decision became final and enforceable .

CARDINAL . A writ of execution was issued for the enforcement of the ORG decision on DATE , as a result of which ORG ’s property – a light bulb factory – was seized by ORG . There is no information regarding any developments in the proceedings following the seizure .
CARDINAL . On an unspecified date in DATE the applicant fled the country and was granted political asylum in GPE . He did not return to GPE until DATE .

CARDINAL . By a request of ORG shareholders which had reached the registry on DATE , ORG declared bankruptcy proceedings open in respect of PERSON on DATE . In the light of reports and inspections conducted by the general assembly of creditors , the court decided that no reorganisation plan could be considered viable as the company did not have the financial means by which to satisfy the requests of its creditors .

CARDINAL . By a decision of CARDINAL DATE , ORG approved the list of creditors that had been drawn up by the assembly of creditors , including the outstanding amounts due . It would appear that ORG shareholders omitted the applicant ’s name from the list of creditors that they had submitted to the ORG pursuant to section CARDINAL of LAW DATE . Consequently , the applicant ’s name was not included in the list of creditors approved by ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG further declared the company bankrupt and recognised the creditors as the shareholders of its assets . It assigned an administrator ( administrator ) , who , together with the creditors , was to proceed with the assessment of the company ’s assets .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant returned to GPE for a visit and enquired about the enforcement of the ORG decision . He was informed that none of ORG ’s property had been seized on his behalf and that , consequently , the DATE decision had not been enforced . The applicant returned to GPE on an unspecified date without taking any action .
CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant returned to GPE and on DATE lodged a request for the enforcement of the ORG decision .
CARDINAL . On DATE the bailiff ordered the seizure of ORG property without specifying it .
CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON ’s property , the light bulb factory , was seized .

CARDINAL . On DATE the bailiff attempted to sell the light bulb factory at a public auction . It transpires that the bailiff ’s office was not aware of ORG decision of DATE regarding the bankruptcy of the company and the appointment of an administrator .

CARDINAL . A letter of DATE was sent by a lawyer to the PERSON tax authorities enquiring about PERSON ’s registration as a commercial entity . A handwritten note in the bottom right - hand corner indicated that no such company was registered with the tax authorities .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date the administrator lodged a complaint with the ORG requesting leave to appeal out of time to enable him to challenge the ORG decision of CARDINAL DATE . The administrator maintained that he had not been aware of that court decision or of the fact that the applicant was CARDINAL of ORG ’s creditors , since the applicant ’s name did not appear on the list of creditors drawn up by ORG ’s shareholders .

CARDINAL . By a decision of DATE ORG granted the administrator ’s action for leave to appeal out of time in accordance with section QUANTITY of LAW . After having initially summoned him to attend the proceedings , ORG proceeded in the applicant ’s absence pursuant to LAW ( “ ORG ” ) as he was not resident in GPE . The applicant became aware of the decision on an unspecified date in DATE and alleged that all time - limits for lodging an appeal had expired by that time .

CARDINAL . On DATE the bailiff ’s office decided to discontinue enforcement of the writ of execution of DATE on the ground that the granting of leave to appeal out of time in the administrator ’s favour had stripped ORG DATE decision of its res judicata effect . The bailiff ’s office indicated that ORG DATE decision did not constitute an enforceable title under the ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the administrator lodged an appeal with ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) , claiming that there had been serious procedural irregularities in the proceedings that had led to the DATE court decision .
CARDINAL . Unable to locate the applicant in order to summon him to the hearing , on DATE ORG issued a public notice for the hearing of DATE pursuant to LAW ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG decided to quash the ORG decision of DATE on account of serious procedural irregularities . It found that ORG had failed to notify and summon the other CARDINAL shareholders of the company . It finally remitted the case for fresh examination . The relevant parts of the decision read as follows .

“ By not properly determining the parties to the proceedings and by not notifying the parties of the time and date of the hearing , the examination of this case was in serious breach of procedural rules and violated the provisions of LAW ) and ( d ) of the ORG .

The first - instance court started the examination of the case without notifying the defendant [ that is , the company ] . It erred in the determination of the parties to the proceedings , because it failed to obtain important evidence such as the [ company ’s ] articles of association , its statute and the court decision , from which it could have found out who to summon to the hearing and the exact address of the company ’s seat . The court only summoned PERSON , who was CARDINAL of the shareholders . There is no evidence in the case file that he was authorised , or had any other prerogative , to represent the company or take actions in its name . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG issued a public notice stating the outcome of its decision .
CARDINAL . Following CARDINAL unsuccessful attempts to summon the applicant to a hearing , on DATE ORG issued a public notice to notify the applicant of the hearing of DATE pursuant to LAW ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG decided in the applicant ’s absence to terminate the proceedings in accordance with LAW ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the administrator requested the prosecutor ’s office to institute criminal proceedings against ORG for the criminal offence of drawing up false statements , having regard to the incorrect information he had submitted in the course of the bankruptcy proceedings ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor ’s office declined the request on the strength of the statute of limitations and LAW .

CARDINAL . By note verbale of DATE , which was registered at the ORG General on DATE , ORG , in accordance with LAW , informed the Secretary General of ORG intention to derogate from its obligations under the Convention . The relevant parts of the note verbale read as follows ( extracted from the original in LANGUAGE ) .

“ I. In compliance with LAW No CARDINAL , dated DATE , " On LAW " , on the proposal of the Government , ORG of GPE took the decision to declare a state of public emergency . Such a situation will be general , covering the entire territory of GPE . It started from DATE , TIME , and will continue up to the moment of the full reinstatement of constitutional and public order .

II . The imposition of the state of public emergency was forced because of the very extraordinary situation that was created in DATE in GPE . Some forces , making use of the protests and the despair of citizens who lost their money from the failure of financial pyramid schemes , organised groups of terrorists to perform violent actions . Without organising peaceful gatherings , these groups violated the law , the constitutional order , the life of the citizens , institutions and the territorial integrity of the country , creating thereby conditions to plunge GPE into a civil war . Being faced with these attacks of extreme violence , the police forces have preserved selfcontrol , by taking only defensive positions and making no use of firearms , which avoided the prospect of a conflict with unpredictable consequences . DATE , the situation had become extremely complicated , and reached a climax at the moment when the imposition of the state of emergency was being discussed .

Though the Government made a proposal , ORG , after a wide and public discussion , with the intervention of the President of the Republic , refused the proclamation of a public emergency and ordered the temporary placement of some army troops to help the police forces . With a view to having a dialogue and awaiting the response of the protestors , the ORG resigned .

On DATE , a communist armed rebellion broke out in PERSON and adjacent regions organised by the former NORP communists and the former NORP secret police , in collaboration with foreign secret services . Terrorist groups attacked the NORP cities to take power by force of arms . The target of their attacks were innocent people , municipalities , and the headquarters of the police ; jails were broken and ordinary criminals and killers were armed , CARDINAL of PERSON were robbed from the banks ; the houses of citizens and the shops of the businessmen were attacked . The clear aim was to terrorise the population , to paralyse and to take over power by force .

IV . According to ORG , dated CARDINAL ‘ For ORG in Case of Grave Infringement of the Constitutional and Public Order’ , in the event that the state of public emergency is announced , a regime of special measures is to be established . ORG lead all ORG activity to be aimed at dealing with the state of public emergency . Under that state of public emergency , GPE took several measures derogating from its international obligations . Those derogations are made to the extent strictly required by the exigency of the situation , not inconsistent with our constitutional law ‘ For FAC , nor with international treaties to which ORG is a party , in particular LAW Freedoms’ and LAW . They were made only for a restricted period of time . These derogations consist of restricting some human rights and fundamental freedoms of individuals . With regard to that issue , LAW . DATE , dated CARDINAL " For ORG " , provides that " The exercise of some specific rights may be temporarily restricted by law in a situation of national emergency or war , with the exclusion of the rights provided for in DATE ( right to life ) ... , CARDINAL ( abolition of torture ) , CARDINAL ( no enforcement to confess one ’s guilt ) , DATE ( freedom of conscience and religion ) , DATE ( equality before the law ) , DATE ( judicial restitution of the right ) , and CARDINAL ( guarantee of a fair trial ) " .

According to ORG , dated CARDINAL ‘ For ORG in Case of Grave Infringement of the Constitutional and Public Order’ , as well as the Law ‘ On Some Measures in the Context of ORG , the specific restrictions on human rights and fundamental freedoms , entailed by these derogations from our international legal obligations , are as follows :

CARDINAL . All armed rebels must hand over arms , munitions and explosives by DATE , TIME . After this deadline , the armed rebels in the battlefield will be shot without warning ( Article CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . All the gatherings in public places are forbidden ( LAW
CARDINAL . All activities of political , sport , cultural or trade union nature are forbidden ( LAW .
CARDINAL . The free movement of people is forbidden during defined TIME of the day ( DATE TIME ) ( Article CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Illegal gatherings in public places shall be dispersed . In the event that it is impossible to carry out such dispersal by other means , the police units are entitled to use tear - gas , as well as firearms , to the extent indispensable to carry out their own duty according to the law ( LAW .

CARDINAL . Limits are imposed on the freedom of press and information . Publication and distribution in the press and broadcasts on the radio of reports which stir up and call for violent actions against national security , the constitutional law , public security and the life of the individual are prohibited . Daily press and media are obliged to publish the full text of the official reports which are directly related to the state of emergency . Press organs are obliged to obtain an approval , prior to sale , of the material intended to be published , from the local staff responsible for execution of the state of emergency . The local staff has the right to suspend any publication which violates this provision ( DATE ) .

CARDINAL . The relevant case - law of ORG concerning the breach of an appellant ’s right of access to court on account of the nonenforcement of a final court ruling has been described in detail in the case of GPE v. GPE , no . CARDINAL , § § CARDINAL–CARDINAL , CARDINAL DATE .
CARDINAL . The relevant parts of the ORG read as follows .

“ In the event that the receiver [ of the summons ] does not have a living abode , residence or temporary home in GPE or has not provided an address or appointed a representative ... , he shall be notified of the [ hearing ] by way of posting a copy of the document at the tribunal of the location where the dispute shall be heard as well as on the notice board of the administrative entity where he used to reside and , when that is unknown , of that of his place of birth .

In the event that GPE has entered into bilateral or multilateral agreements , the above - cited provision shall apply only in so far as the notification is not possible in one of the ways envisaged in those agreements . ”

“ If the plaintiff or any of the parties do not attend either the preparatory meeting or the hearing after having been duly notified and without reasonable grounds , the court or the single judge shall decide to terminate the proceedings ( vendos pushimin e gjykimit ) .

“ Each party may summon to the trial of the case a person with whom he or she believes he or she has a shared interest in the case or from whom a guarantee or compensation may be requested if necessary for the completion of the case .
A third party can be summoned when he or she has a known place of abode within the borders of GPE and as long as the trial of the case is still pending at first instance . ”
“ A party which has forfeited the right to appeal on reasonable grounds may submit a request to the court which adopted the decision for leave to appeal out of time . ... ”

by the court which made the decision in the cases provided for in sub - sections ( a ) ... of the foregoing Article . ”

The seizure shall be registered at ORG for the area where the writ of execution was issued . The entry in the register shall indicate the type , nature and [ a description of ] CARDINAL borders of the immovable property , its location and any mortgage or other property rights attached to it .

CARDINAL . LAW DATE , as in force at the material time , provided that bankruptcy proceedings were to be conducted in court ( section CARDINAL ) . Were the proceedings to start on the strength of a legal action by the creditor , he would need to prove that the debtor had defaulted on payment . In any event , the debtor could also file a similar action ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . During the proceedings , the court could question witnesses , summon experts and hear evidence from the debtor ( sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) , who was obliged to submit to the court , inter alia , an accurate list of all his assets and their corresponding value , a list of creditors with their names and addresses and the amount owed to each of them and a list of any debtors with the corresponding amounts they owed to him . The debtor assumed criminal responsibility for the veracity of the lists ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The opening of bankruptcy proceedings took place on the strength of a court decision , which would , inter alia , fix a time - limit by which all creditors could submit their claims and the respective sums in NORP leks , state the grounds that gave rise to their participation in the bankruptcy proceedings as well as give their accord for the distribution of sums obtained from the bankruptcy proceedings ( section CARDINAL ) . The district court would also decide to place the debtor under compulsory administration by appointing an administrator .

CARDINAL . By virtue of the opening of bankruptcy proceedings , the debtor lost the right to possess and administer all his present and future property . Any civil and arbitration proceedings in which the debtor was a party were suspended on the initiation of bankruptcy proceedings . ORG rulings given before the initiation of bankruptcy proceedings in respect of the enforcement of a court decision were no longer binding at the start of bankruptcy proceedings ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . In the course of the discharge of his duties , the administrator acted under the supervision of the court , which was empowered to replace him , stating reasons ( section DATE ) . In accordance with section CARDINAL , the administrator could lodge a civil claim against the debtor ’s legal actions in the event that the debtor had intentionally made the position of CARDINAL of the creditors worse and when this was known to the third party ; or if , in DATE the opening of the bankruptcy proceedings , the debtor had intentionally made [ the creditors’ ] position worse in favour of other persons , in so far as this can be proved and in so far as the administrator was unaware of the disadvantage suffered .

CARDINAL . LAW DATE provided for the possibility of drafting a restructuring plan ( plani i riorganizimit ) , with a view to final liquidation of the debtor . Such a plan required the court ’s approval ( section CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) . The administrator then proceeded with the liquidation of the debtor and the distribution of the sums collected to the creditors in accordance with the table of outstanding dues that had been approved by the court ( section CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . LAW DATE was repealed by PERSON no . DATE , dated DATE .
